Hey Reymond,

I agree with both your points. And I got a little advice for =
you when
using Buckland's NEAT Code.
In the Cga::ResetAndKill there is a bu=
g which can cause a program
crash, because the iterator is decremented, whi=
ch also could happen
when pointing at to the first element.

 -- Robin

---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Raymond Von Wahlde" <rvonwahlde@...> wrote:
>
> =
I am working at creating a version NEAT in National Instrument's 
> LabView=
.  I am using Buckland's NEAT for Windows code as a convention 
> to follow=
.  It has proven extremely helpful and Buckland is to be 
> commended for h=
is comments and consistancy.
> 
> There is a small section of code in the C=
Genome::AddLink function 
> that as far as I can determine serves no purpos=
e and may be an 
> artifact from when it was originally written:
> 
>      =
 if (ID_neuron2 =3D=3D 2)
>       {
>         continue;
>       }
> 
> What=
 possible reason would it matter if this statement were true or 
> false?
>=
 
> Also, Buckland's sigmoid function is written as:
> 
> //---------------=
---------------------Sigmoid function----------------
> //
> //------------=
--------------------------------------------------------
> 
> float Sigmoid=
(float netinput, float response)
> {
> 	return ( 1 / ( 1 + exp(-netinput / =
response)));
> }
> 
> where "response" is the dActivationResponse value whi=
ch one can 
> choose to mutate.
> 
> I understand that this changes the slo=
pe of the sigmoid curve.  
> Wouldn't it be better to multiply "netinput" b=
y "response" so a case 
> of dividing by zero does not ever occur?
> 
> Tha=
nks
> 
> Raymond
>
